title: R41822
content: The 112th Congress is considering legislative proposals to limit the government's risk from Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, government-sponsored enterprises responsible for nearly half of the nation's residential mortgage debt. In 2008, their capital proved inadequate during the financial crisis, leading to government intervention to support the mortgage markets. The U.S. Department of the Treasury purchased over $175 billion in special preferred stock to support Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac during the 2008-2009 financial crisis. Treasury and the Federal Reserve also bought $1.4 trillion in MBS to aid the mortgage market. Legislation may reduce the enterprises' size and increase their costs, potentially impacting mortgage prices and interest rates for borrowers. Several legislative proposals aim to increase costs for Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, potentially impacting mortgage prices and interest rates. These bills include new limitations on mortgage purchases, increased regulatory oversight, higher capital requirements, and a deadline for the enterprises to return to stockholder control or be dissolved. Several legislative proposals aim to address the financial difficulties of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac. Some proposals include setting a deadline for the enterprises to return to stockholder control or be dissolved, while others focus on replacing the enterprises in the secondary mortgage markets. In September 2008, both enterprises entered voluntary conservatorship, with the Federal Housing Finance Agency taking control. The Treasury also signed contracts to provide financial support to keep them solvent. The Federal Housing Finance Agency (FHFA) took control of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac in 2008, with the Treasury signing contracts to provide financial support. The enterprises play a crucial role in the mortgage market by purchasing mortgages from lenders and packaging them into Mortgage-Backed Securities (MBS). The Obama Administration's report presents three alternatives for the future of the enterprises and the housing finance system. The Obama Administration's report presents three alternatives for the future of the housing finance system: a privatized system with government mortgage programs targeted by income or first-time homebuyer status, a privatized system with government guarantee during crises, and a privatized system with government reinsurance of private mortgage insurance. No legislation has been introduced yet to implement these proposals. Legislation introduced in the 112th Congress addresses various concerns, including executive compensation and reforms in different areas. Legislation introduced in the 112th Congress addresses concerns such as executive compensation and reforms in different areas. H.R. 31, Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac Accountability and Transparency for Taxpayers Act of 2011, would require the director of FHFA to make quarterly reports on Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac in 12 specific areas. The bill introduced in the 112th Congress, the Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac Accountability and Transparency for Taxpayers Act of 2011, mandates quarterly reports by the FHFA director on various aspects of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, including equity investments, capital levels, underwriting standards, and mortgage buyback policies. The reports will be reviewed by the FHFA inspector general and posted on the FHFA website. Additionally, the IG will examine FHFA's loss mitigation policies and their impact on the enterprises' financial condition and foreclosure rates. The FHFA's reporting requirements overlap with current reports, covering capital, investments, and loss mitigation activities. Legislation like H.R. 463 and H.R. 1221 aim to increase transparency and limit executive compensation at Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac. No action has been taken on these bills yet. H.R. 1221, the Equity in Government Compensation Act of 2011, aims to limit executive pay at Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac. It proposes suspending current executive compensation packages and setting a maximum pay for employees. The bill also includes provisions on executive compensation and corporate governance, but states that enterprise employees will not be considered federal employees. The House Financial Services Committee ordered the bill to be reported as amended on November 15, 2011. The House Financial Services Committee ordered the bill to be reported as amended on November 15, 2011. The bill would remove FHFA's discretion in rejecting enterprise salaries. H.R. 1222, GSE Subsidy Elimination Act of 2011, would require the enterprises to charge a guarantee fee reflecting mortgage risk and capital costs. FHFA could phase in the higher fee over two years or impose it at the higher level two years after enactment. The House Subcommittee on Capital Markets and Government-Sponsored Enterprises marked up H.R. 1222 and forwarded it to the full committee. FHFA has the authority to implement the provisions as conservator or receiver. H.R. 1223, GSE Credit Risk Equitable Treatment Act of 2011, would prohibit treating mortgage-backed securities issued by the enterprises differently. Dodd-Frank requires joint regulations to implement risk retention requirements for mortgages. The Dodd-Frank Act requires joint regulations to implement risk retention requirements for mortgages included in MBS. QRMs would be exempt from this requirement. The Federal Reserve's general counsel testified that the enterprises' guarantees may satisfy the risk retention requirements if they are in conservatorship or receivership. H.R. 1224, GSE Portfolio Risk Reduction Act of 2011, would address this issue. The proposed rules would allow enterprises' guarantees to satisfy risk retention requirements if they are in conservatorship or receivership. H.R. 1224 aims to reduce Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac's portfolios to $250 billion each over five years. Various companion bills also propose portfolio reductions on similar schedules. H.R. 1224 excludes delinquent mortgages repurchased to fulfill guarantees from portfolio limits. H.R. 1224 compares portfolio caps under the current agreement and companion bills. It excludes delinquent mortgages from portfolio limits. FHFA could order rapid portfolio reductions. H.R. 1225 requires Treasury approval for new debt issuance by enterprises. Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac's charters are mentioned. The House Subcommittee on Capital Markets and Government-Sponsored Enterprises marked up H.R. 1225, requiring Treasury approval for new debt issuance by Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac. The Secretary of the Treasury could assert existing review authority in the enterprises' charters. H.R. 1226 would repeal affordable housing goals established in previous acts. H.R. 1226, the GSE Mission Improvement Act, aims to repeal affordable housing goals and duties to serve underserved markets. It also eliminates funding for housing trust and capital magnet funds. FHFA must report to Congress on the bill's impact on multifamily properties and loans to low-income and rural borrowers. The House Subcommittee on Capital Markets and Government-Sponsored Enterprises forwarded H.R. 1226 to the full committee for consideration. H.R. 1227, GSE Risk and Activities Limitation Act of 2011, would restrict new product approvals for enterprises in conservatorship or receivership. FHFA would retain approval authority when enterprises are not in conservatorship. H.R. 2425, Transparency and Security in Mortgage Registration Act of 2011, aims to prohibit GSEs from purchasing mortgages registered with MERS, a system bypassing state registration laws. MERS is a centralized mortgage registration system bypassing state laws. Legal challenges question its authority in foreclosures. H.R. 2428 addresses legal expenses for employees. H.R. 2436 prevents reduction in dividend rates paid to Treasury. H.R. 2439 empowers during receivership. H.R. 2436, Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac Taxpayer Payback Act of 2011, prevents reduction in dividend rates paid to Treasury. H.R. 2439 empowers FHFA to revoke an enterprise's charter during receivership. H.R. 2441 terminates Housing Trust Fund, Capital Magnet Fund, and Hope Reserve Fund. H.R. 2440 directs FHFA to identify and sell non-mission critical assets held by the enterprises. The Market Transparency and Taxpayer Protection Act of 2011 directs FHFA to identify non-mission critical assets held by Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, including patents and mortgage data, and submit a plan to sell them. The Cap the GSE Bailout Act of 2011 sets a maximum amount of support for each enterprise in the Preferred Stock Purchase Agreements, with the possibility of additional financial support if needed. Treasury has provided support through purchasing preferred stock, initially at $100 billion per GSE, later raised to $200 billion each, with unlimited support in 2010-2012 and $200 billion limits outside of those years. In late 2009, the PSPA were amended to provide unlimited support for Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac in 2010-2012, with $200 billion limits outside of those years. Various companion bills have been introduced in Congress, including H.R. 408, S. 178, H.R. 1182, and S. 693, with different provisions for the enterprises. H.R. 1859 and H.R. 2413 propose replacing the enterprises. H.R. 408 and S. 178, titled the Spending Reduction Act of 2011, address multiple issues beyond Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac reform. Title VI of these bills aims to terminate the enterprises' conservatorships within 24 months. Title VI of the GSE Bailout Elimination and Taxpayer Protection Act aims to terminate Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac's conservatorships within 24 months. After leaving conservatorship, the enterprises would need to reduce their portfolios to $250 billion each over four years and would no longer have housing goals. Certain provisions in other bills are not included in this more narrowly focused legislation. The GSE Bailout Elimination and Taxpayer Protection Act aims to terminate Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac's conservatorships within 24-30 months. After leaving conservatorship, the enterprises would either be returned to stockholder control or dissolved under receivership. FHFA would have strengthened authority to set and enforce minimum capital levels. The conforming loan limit would be set at $417,000 nationwide with no high-cost exceptions, and the enterprises would be prohibited from purchasing mortgages above the area median home price. The GSE Bailout Elimination and Taxpayer Protection Act aims to terminate Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac's conservatorships within 24-30 months. The conforming loan limit is currently $417,000, except in high-cost areas where it is higher with a maximum of $625,500. The enterprises would be prohibited from purchasing mortgages greater than the area median home price. The minimum downpayment for mortgages purchased by the enterprises would be 5% during the first 12 months after leaving conservatorship, 7.5% during the second 12 months, and 10% afterward. The enterprises would be required to pay all state and local taxes and register all stocks and public offerings with the SEC. FHFA would charge each enterprise for the value of the benefits provided by the government. The GSE Bailout Elimination and Taxpayer Protection Act aims to terminate Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac's conservatorships within 24-30 months. The bill includes provisions such as charging each enterprise for the benefits provided by the government, increasing guarantee fees, reducing portfolios to $250 billion each over five years, and repealing affordable housing goals. Additionally, it would end the enterprises' conservatorship in 24 months, start phasing out their charters for new business three years after leaving conservatorship, and repeal their exemption from SEC registration. The GSE Bailout Elimination and Taxpayer Protection Act aims to terminate Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac's conservatorships within 24-30 months. Provisions include ending conservatorship in 24 months, phasing out charters for new business three years after, repealing exemption from SEC registration, lowering conforming loan limit, increasing minimum capital requirements, raising borrower downpayment requirements, and requiring payment of state and local taxes. H.R. 1859 would authorize FHFA to charter housing finance guaranty associations for mortgage securitization. The Housing Finance Reform Act of 2011 would authorize FHFA to charter housing finance guaranty associations to pool and securitize single-family and multifamily mortgages. The associations would guarantee timely payment to investors, with a federal backup guarantee. They would be restricted to purchasing existing mortgages and could specialize in specific markets. The maximum mortgage size would be based on national or area median prices, with limits ranging from $256,000 to $897,300. Mortgages on one-to-four family units could be purchased with an 80% loan-to-value ratio or seller participation. The Housing Finance Reform Act of 2011 authorizes FHFA to charter housing finance guaranty associations to pool and securitize single-family and multifamily mortgages. Associations would guarantee timely payment to investors with a federal backup guarantee. They could specialize in specific markets and purchase mortgages with an 80% loan-to-value ratio or seller participation. H.R. 2413, Secondary Market Facility for Residential Mortgages Act of 2011, would create a federal corporation to purchase and securitize mortgages meeting underwriting standards. The facility would charge guarantee and reinsurance fees, aiming to keep its market share under 50%. The proposed facility would charge guarantee and reinsurance fees for purchasing mortgages, aiming to keep its market share under 50%. The guarantee fee would cover mortgage payments during normal times, while the reinsurance fee would compensate Treasury for the federal guarantee. Mortgages eligible for purchase would be for 30 years or less, with a maximum size based on a formula used in FY2011. The reorganized FHFA would oversee the facility.
